docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The issue of mistreatment of the prisoners incarcerated at Guantánamo Bay has included descriptions of bug-infested quarters, terrible meals, facilities without adequate plumbing and the like (front page, Jan. 23). This could al...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The issue of mistreatment of the prisoners incarcerated at Guantánamo Bay has included descriptions of bug-infested quarters, terrible meals, facilities without adequate plumbing and the like (front page, Jan. 23). This could also describe my experience at Fort Benning, Ga., as an Army reservist called up for the Bosnian conflict.
docs.abstract: Letter from Gordon Tagge says descriptions of bug-infested quarters at Guantanamo Bay could also describe his experience at Fort Benning, Ga, as Army reservist (Jan 23 article)

docs.snippet: Four representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross arrived here today to determine whether the United States is mistreating prisoners from Afghanistan as international human rights groups have contended.    ''We will look at trea...
docs.lead_paragraph: Four representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross arrived here today to determine whether the United States is mistreating prisoners from Afghanistan as international human rights groups have contended. ''We will look at treatment, at conditions, and we will share our findings confidentially with the detaining authority,'' said Urs Boegli, who is based in Washington and leads the four-member Red Cross team. The group includes a medical doctor, a linguist from Russia and an incarceration specialist.
docs.abstract: Four representatives of International Committee of Red Cross arrive at Guantanamo Bay Naval Station to determine whether United States is mistreating prisoners from Afghanistan as international human rights groups contend; photo (M)

headline.main: Red Cross Team Will Examine Prisoners From Afghanistan

docs.snippet: When Hamid Karzai was handed the wispy reins of power as interim leader of Afghanistan early this month, not all Americans asked, ''Who?''    Some people, led by two of his brothers, Mahmood and Qayum Karzai, proudly proclaimed the inevitability o...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Hamid Karzai was handed the wispy reins of power as interim leader of Afghanistan early this month, not all Americans asked, ''Who?'' Some people, led by two of his brothers, Mahmood and Qayum Karzai, proudly proclaimed the inevitability of the choice as they celebrated the news by satellite telephone with Hamid Karzai at the clan's American power base here in the affluent suburbs set amid farm fields west of Baltimore.
docs.abstract: Hamid Karzai, Afghanistan's interim leader, has American network of four brothers and one sister, all naturalized citizens, who challenge and bolster him in nightly phone calls; also has two brothers in Pakistan to offer advice; brothers Mahmood and Qayum, successful restaurant owners in Maryland comment, interview; photos (M)

headline.main: For Afghan Leader, American Support of Another Sort

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Bush, Focusing on Terrorism, Says Secure U.S. Is Top Priority'' (front page, Jan. 30):...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bush, Focusing on Terrorism, Says Secure U.S. Is Top Priority'' (front page, Jan. 30):
docs.abstract: Joan Carrigan letter on Jan 30 article deplores Pres Bush's failure to fully credit Britain and other allies in State of Union message for joining us in war on terrorism

headline.main: Sept. 11 and the State of the Union

docs.snippet: Smarting a bit from criticism by international human rights groups, United States troops here who received 30 new prisoners from the war on terrorism in Afghanistan were determined today to show that their captives would be treated properly.    ''...
docs.lead_paragraph: Smarting a bit from criticism by international human rights groups, United States troops here who received 30 new prisoners from the war on terrorism in Afghanistan were determined today to show that their captives would be treated properly. ''Each detainee has an Isomat to lay on,'' said Brig. Gen. Mike Lehnert, holding up an inch-thick piece of olive-drab foam to show reporters. ''It isn't particularly comfortable. It is also the same thing issued every day to our soldiers and marines in the field. I myself have spent a good portion of my Marine Corps career on one of these mats.''
docs.abstract: United States troops at Guantanamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba seek to show that their prisoners from war on terrorism in Afghanistan will be treated properly; there has been criticism by international human rights groups about prisoners' treatment; Brig Gen Michael Lehnert describes living conditions for prisoners; photos (M)

headline.main: On Defensive, General Says Prisoners Get Mats, Even Bagels

docs.snippet: George W. Bush is spending the days before New Year's at his ranch in Crawford, Tex., enjoying the kind of informal, secluded weekend he has probably envisioned having many times during his presidency. And the public, much of which was once prepar...
docs.lead_paragraph: George W. Bush is spending the days before New Year's at his ranch in Crawford, Tex., enjoying the kind of informal, secluded weekend he has probably envisioned having many times during his presidency. And the public, much of which was once prepared to resent Mr. Bush's desire to get away from Washington as much as possible, now simply hopes he gets to catch up on his sleep. It has been a far different first year than the one the president, or the country, anticipated. Mr. Bush heads toward his second year at the White House with his presidency transformed by crisis and the nation propelled by a renewed sense of purpose. He hardly seems like the same chief executive who squeaked into office thanks to a badly designed ballot in some Florida counties, let alone the candidate who was embarrassed by his inability to name the general running Pakistan. Mr. Bush, whose critics worried that he would never be able to conduct foreign diplomacy, has proved himself a strong wartime leader who gives the nation a sense of security during a period of crisis.
docs.abstract: Editorial on Pres Bush's first year in office holds has emerged as larger, graver figure; sees him as strong wartime leader who gives nation sense of security during crisis period; questions whether he can trim his early impulse toward unilateral thinking and conservative ideology in ways that will let him maintain international antiterrorism alliance; holds he has shown he has talents to fashion strong legislative agenda that can be passed into law; notes it is not clear whether he will use talents to create moderate, bipartisan domestic agenda

docs.snippet: The House attached a series of conditions to American aid to Colombia today, demanding that the government hold right-wing paramilitary groups and their military allies accountable for violence there. The Senate, which initiated the restrictions, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The House attached a series of conditions to American aid to Colombia today, demanding that the government hold right-wing paramilitary groups and their military allies accountable for violence there. The Senate, which initiated the restrictions, is expected to concur. Under the conditions, the secretary of state must certify that the commander of the Colombian armed forces suspends troops that violate human rights and make them available for prosecution in civilian courts. The Colombian military must also sever links to paramilitary groups that have thrived, often with military intelligence and supplies, in an increasingly brutal showdown with leftist guerrillas.
docs.abstract: US House attaches series of conditions to American aid to Colombia, demanding that government hold right-wing paramilitary groups and their military allies accountable for violence and abuses; Senate, which initiated restrictions, is expected to concur; at stake is more than $300 million in US assistance (M)

headline.main: U.S. Tells Colombia to Improve Rights Record Before It Gets Aid

docs.snippet: Three marines were wounded by a land mine today, one of them seriously, at the airport outside Kandahar as they worked to clear an airport building of mines, booby traps and unexploded ordnance, Marine spokesmen said.    The men were quickly evacu...
docs.lead_paragraph: Three marines were wounded by a land mine today, one of them seriously, at the airport outside Kandahar as they worked to clear an airport building of mines, booby traps and unexploded ordnance, Marine spokesmen said. The men were quickly evacuated to the field hospital at Camp Rhino, the original Marine outpost in southern Afghanistan, officials at that base said. One of them, who lost his leg below the knee when he stepped on the mine, was evacuated from Afghanistan to an Air Force hospital in the Persian Gulf area.
docs.abstract: Three marines are wounded by land mine, one seriously, while working to clear Kandahar, Afghanistan, airport of unexploded ordnance; are first marines seriously hurt since hundreds began arriving in area Nov 25; photos (M)

headline.main: 3 Marines Wounded by Land Mine at Kandahar Airport

byline.original: By ERIK ECKHOLM with STEVEN LEE MYERS

docs.snippet: Gul Agha Shirzai, the new governor of Kandahar, had reason to look contented as he sat in the palace here today, picking at raisins and nuts as he received tribal leaders and militia commanders and smiled for the cameras of foreign journalists.   ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gul Agha Shirzai, the new governor of Kandahar, had reason to look contented as he sat in the palace here today, picking at raisins and nuts as he received tribal leaders and militia commanders and smiled for the cameras of foreign journalists. Hundreds more turbaned Afghan men milled inside and outside the receiving room in a raucous scene that Mr. Shirzai, a bearish, gruff man in his mid-40's, seemed to relish.
docs.abstract: Interview with Kandahar's new governor, Gul Agha Shirzai, Afghan warlord who occupied palace after seven years of exile, pre-empting rivals by swooping in first with most troops; he pledges to get guns off streets, restart schools and wipe out last remnants of Al Qaeda, interview; was last governor of province before it fell to Taliban in 1994; photo (M)

headline.main: Meet the New Warlord, Same as the Old One

docs.snippet: A profile on Friday about Hervé Djamel Loiseau, a Frenchman who fought for Al Qaeda and died near Tora Bora, Afghanistan, misspelled the name of the theater in Paris where his father worked and took him to meet star entertainers. It is the Olympi...
docs.lead_paragraph: A profile on Friday about Hervé Djamel Loiseau, a Frenchman who fought for Al Qaeda and died near Tora Bora, Afghanistan, misspelled the name of the theater in Paris where his father worked and took him to meet star entertainers. It is the Olympia, not the Olympic.
docs.abstract: Correction of Dec 28 profile of Herve Djamel Loiseau, Frenchman who died fighting for Al Qaeda in Afghanistan, which misspelled name of Paris theater
